awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Modeling ice-ocean Interaction for the Rapidly Evolving Ice Shelf Cavities of Pine Island and Thwaites Glaciers, Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
The West Antarctic Ice Sheet contains enough ice to raise global sea levels by 3-4 meters. Ice-sheet volume falls, and sea level increases, when more ice is lost to the ocean by glacier flow than is replaced by snowfall. Glacier speed is reduced when ice shelves, which are the floating extensions of the ice sheets, are present. Processes that affect ice shelf thickness and extent therefore influence the rates of grounded ice loss and sea-level rise. West Antarctica is currently losing ice, at an accelerating rate, with most loss occurring in the Amundsen Sea region via discharge from Pine Island and Thwaites glaciers. This loss was initiated by increased circulation of relatively warm ocean water beneath these glacier's ice shelves, causing them to thin by melting. However, this melting also depends on how the changing shape of the ice shelves affects the ocean circulation beneath them and the speeds of the grounded glaciers upstream. Limited understanding of these processes leads to uncertainties in estimates of future ice loss. This interdisciplinary project brings together glaciologists and oceanographers from three US institutions to study the interactions between changing glacier flow, ice shelf shape and extent, and ocean circulation. Data and numerical models will be used to identify the key processes that determine how rapidly this region can shed ice. The project team will train postdocs and graduate students in cutting-edge modeling techniques, and educate the public about Antarctic ice loss through talks, school science fairs, and Seattle Science Center's annual Polar Science Weekend. 

The project team will conduct simulations, using a combination of ice-sheet and ocean models, to reduce uncertainties in projected ice loss from Pine Island and Thwaites glaciers by: (i) assessing how ice-shelf melt rates will change as the ice-shelf cavities evolve through melting and grounding-line retreat, and (ii) improving understanding of the sensitivity of sub-shelf melt rates to changes in ocean state on the nearby continental shelf. These studies will reduce uncertainty on ice loss and sea-level rise estimates, and lay the groundwork for development of future fully-coupled ice-sheet/ocean models. The project will first develop high-resolution ice-shelf-cavity circulation models driven by modern observed regional ocean state and validated with estimates of melt derived from satellite observations. Next, an ice-flow model will be used to estimate the future grounding retreat. An iterative process with the ocean-circulation and ice-flow models will then simulate melt rates at each stage of retreat. These results will help assess the validity of the hypothesis that unstable collapse of the Amundsen Sea sector of West Antarctica is underway, which was based on simplified models of melt rate. These models will also provide a better understanding of the sensitivity of melt to regional forcing such as changes in Circumpolar Deep Water temperature and wind-driven changes in thermocline height. Finally, several semi-coupled ice-ocean simulations will help determine the influence of the ocean-circulation driven melt over the next several decades. These simulations will provide a much-improved understanding of the linkages between far-field ocean forcing, cavity circulation and melting, and ice-sheet response.

por.por_cntn:
The Antarctic Ice Sheet resting on the Antarctic continent contains enough ice to raise global sea level by about 60 meters. The ice flows towards the ocean and, in many places, develops a thick, floating ice shelf. Friction at contact points between ice shelves and islands, seabed bumps and the coast provides resistance that slows the seaward flow of grounded ice, helping to maintain the ice sheet. Any loss of ice from an ice shelf increases ice sheet loss.

Some Antarctic ice shelves are close to steady state, where the ice gained by flow from the grounded ice sheet plus snowfall on the ice shelf is balanced by losses from ocean-driven melting at the ice-shelf base, and iceberg calving; however, some are losing far more ice than they gain, either by excess melting or calving. Rapid thinning is of special interest for Pine Island, Thwaites and other ice shelves around the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, where a deep layer of relatively warm water causes rapid melting. Measurements and models indicate that, because of long-term changes in regional winds, more of this warm water is reaching the ice shelves and thinning them, and the nearby grounded ice is also accelerating and thinning.

Most previous work on this topic has studied relationships between winds, ocean, ice shelves and grounded ice with relatively simple one-way forcing models. For example: If the ocean under the ice shelf is warmed by one degree, how much faster does the ice shelf melt? And: If the ice shelf thins by, say, 50 meters, how does the grounded-ice flow change?  However, the system contains strong feedbacks; e.g., increased melting of ice shelves produces more fresh water, which changes the ocean structure near the ice shelves and modifies how the subsurface warm water responds to winds.

This project aimed to increase our understanding of these feedbacks and explore the technical demands of coupled models. We carried out four related tasks.

(1) We created a new computer model of the ocean circulation and basal melting for Pine Island Glacier's ice shelf, and tested how our predictions of basal melt rates depend on the model?s representation of poorly understood physical processes. We determined which model versions yielded the most realistic circulation under the ice shelf by comparing the simulations with measured melt rates.

(2) We coupled our ocean model to an ice sheet model developed independently by European colleagues. Rather than developing a custom technique for coupling models, we used the recently developed Framework for Ice Sheet-Ocean Coupling (FISOC).  FISOC provides a general software framework that can be adapted to a wide variety of ocean and ice sheet models.

"Coupling" means that the basal melting predicted by the ocean model was fed to the ice sheet model to predict changes in the ice shelf and ice sheet, which were then fed back to the ocean model. The two models advance together in time, enabling new phenomena that cannot be simulated using each model individually. An example of such co-evolution is the so-called "marine ice sheet instability" in which changes in the basal melt rate and retreat of the grounding line develop a self-reinforcing feedback loop that accelerates ice sheet loss and consequent sea level rise.

The different physics of liquid water (ocean) and solid water (ice sheet) lead to different computational needs. Models of sea water must capture phenomena that occur over a matter of seconds while models of the ice sheet flow need only to represent phenomena with time scales of weeks or more. When the variables of the models are represented on spatial grids, the grid points do not match up. We address time and spatial differences between the models by interpolating between the respective model grids and time steps. Our demonstration of the usefulness of FISOC in this regional application paves the way for future use in large-scale climate models.

(3) We collaborated on a study of the role of eddies in carrying water north and south across the continental shelf and ice front for a large, "cold water" ice shelf environment that is distinct from the Pine Island region. This study shows that we need to resolve eddies in the ocean component of coupled models for all Antarctic regions. 

(4) We contributed to two studies of how ice shelf velocities respond to the annual cycles of ocean forcing. These studies revealed that spatial patterns of seasonal cycles of basal melting, and of sea surface height, can drive ice velocity changes; however, these changes are sensitive to how ice-sheet models represent ice behavior near where the ice sheet first transitions to a floating ice shelf. We can use the strong annual cycles of ocean and atmosphere forcing to improve our understanding of coupled processes at decadal and longer timescales that are of interest for sea level rise.
